cleaned_text: Vaccine |Vaccine| [D014612](https://meshb.nlm.nih.gov/record/ui?ui=D014612) |Part of |[Vaccination](/wiki/Vaccination) A vaccine is a biological [preparation](/wiki/Dosage_form) that provides active [acquired immunity](/wiki/Acquired_immunity) to a particular [infectious](/wiki/Infectious_disease) or [malignant](/wiki/Cancer) disease. [[1]](#cite_note-iac39-1) [[2]](#cite_note-2) The safety and effectiveness of vaccines has been widely studied and verified. [[3]](#cite_note-AmannaSlifka2018-3) [[4]](#cite_note-<ref_name=-4) A vaccine typically contains an agent that resembles a disease-causing microorganism and is often made from weakened or [killed forms of the microbe, its toxins, or one of its surface proteins](/wiki/Antigen). The agent stimulates the body's [immune system](/wiki/Immune_system) to recognize the agent as a threat, destroy it, and to further recognize and destroy any of the microorganisms associated with that agent that it may encounter in the future. Vaccines can be [prophylactic](/wiki/Prophylaxis) (to prevent or ameliorate the effects of a future [infection](/wiki/Infection) by a natural or "wild" [pathogen](/wiki/Pathogen)), or [therapeutic](/wiki/Therapeutic_vaccines) (to fight a disease that has already occurred, such as [cancer](/wiki/Cancer_vaccine)). [[5]](#cite_note-pmid26214521-5) [[6]](#cite_note-pmid26861670-6) [[7]](#cite_note-7) [[8]](#cite_note-pmid24748633-8) Some vaccines offer full [sterilizing immunity](/wiki/Sterilizing_immunity), in which infection is prevented completely. [[9]](#cite_note-9) The administration of vaccines is called [vaccination](/wiki/Vaccination). Vaccination is the most effective method of preventing infectious diseases; [[10]](#cite_note-10) widespread immunity due to vaccination is largely responsible for the [worldwide eradication](/wiki/Eradication_of_infectious_diseases) of [smallpox](/wiki/Smallpox) and the restriction of diseases such as [polio](/wiki/Polio), [measles](/wiki/Measles), and [tetanus](/wiki/Tetanus) from much of the world. The [World Health Organization](/wiki/World_Health_Organization) (WHO) reports that licensed vaccines are currently available for twenty-five different [preventable infections](/wiki/Vaccine-preventable_diseases). [[11]](#cite_note-11) The first recorded use of [inoculation](/wiki/Inoculation) to prevent smallpox occurred in the 16th century in China, with the earliest hints of the practice in China coming during the 10th century. [[12]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliams201060-12) It was also the first disease for which a vaccine was produced. [[13]](#cite_note-pmid17633292-13) [[14]](#cite_note-pmid6319980-14)The folk practice of [inoculation](/wiki/Inoculation) against [smallpox](/wiki/Smallpox) was brought from [Turkey](/wiki/Turkey) to Britain in 1721 by [Lady Mary Wortley Montagu](/wiki/Lady_Mary_Wortley_Montagu). [[15]](#cite_note-Montagu's_bold_experiment-15) The terms vaccine and vaccination are derived from Variolae vaccinae (smallpox of the cow), the term devised by [Edward Jenner](/wiki/Edward_Jenner) (who both developed the concept of vaccines and created the first vaccine) to denote [cowpox](/wiki/Cowpox). He used the phrase in 1798 for the long title of his Inquiry into the Variolae vaccinae Known as the Cow Pox, in which he described the protective effect of cowpox against smallpox. [[16]](#cite_note-Baxby1999-16) In 1881, to honor Jenner, [Louis Pasteur](/wiki/Louis_Pasteur) proposed that the terms should be extended to cover the new protective inoculations then being developed. [[17]](#cite_note-Pasteur1881-17) The science of vaccine development and production is termed [vaccinology](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/vaccinology). Effects There is overwhelming scientific consensus that vaccines are a very safe and effective way to fight and eradicate infectious diseases. [[19]](#cite_note-19) [[20]](#cite_note-20) [[21]](#cite_note-21) [[22]](#cite_note-22) The [immune system](/wiki/Immune_system) recognizes vaccine agents as foreign, destroys them, and "remembers" them. When the [virulent](/wiki/Virulence) version of an agent is encountered, the body recognizes the protein coat on the agent, and thus is prepared to respond, by first neutralizing the target agent before it can enter cells, and secondly by recognizing and destroying infected cells before that agent can multiply to vast numbers. [[23]](#cite_note-Mak-23) [[24]](#cite_note-Clem-24) Limitations to their effectiveness, nevertheless, exist. [[25]](#cite_note-pmid19393917-25) Sometimes, protection fails for vaccine-related reasons such as failures in vaccine attenuation, vaccination regimens or administration. [[26]](#cite_note-wied-26) Failure may also occur for host-related reasons if the host's immune system does not respond adequately or at all. Host-related lack of response occurs in an estimated 2-10% of individuals, due to factors including genetics, immune status, age, health and nutritional status. [[26]](#cite_note-wied-26) One type of [primary immunodeficiency](/wiki/Primary_immunodeficiency) disorder resulting in genetic failure is [X-linked agammaglobulinemia](/wiki/X-linked_agammaglobulinemia), in which the absence of an enzyme essential for [B cell](/wiki/B_cell) development prevents the host's immune from generating [antibodies](/wiki/Antibody) to a [pathogen](/wiki/Pathogen). [[27]](#cite_note-27) [[28]](#cite_note-Reda-28) Host-pathogen interactions and responses to infection are dynamic processes involving multiple pathways in the immune system. [[29]](#cite_note-Jo-29) [[30]](#cite_note-Janeway-30) A host does not develop antibodies instantaneously: while the body's [innate immunity](/wiki/Innate_immunity) may be activated in as little as twelve hours, [adaptive immunity](/wiki/Adaptive_immunity) can take 1-2 weeks to fully develop. During that time, the host can still become infected. [[31]](#cite_note-31) Once antibodies are produced, they may promote immunity in any of several ways, depending on the class of antibodies involved. Their success in clearing or inactivating a pathogen will depend on the amount of antibodies produced and on the extent to which those antibodies are effective at countering the strain of the pathogen involved, since different strains may be differently susceptible to a given immune reaction. [[30]](#cite_note-Janeway-30) In some cases vaccines may result in partial immune protection (in which immunity is less than 100% effective but still reduces risk of infection) or in temporary immune protection (in which immunity wanes over time) rather than full or permanent immunity. They can still raise the reinfection threshold for the population as a whole and make a substantial impact. [[32]](#cite_note-Gomes-32) They can also mitigate the severity of infection, resulting in a lower [mortality rate](/wiki/Mortality_rate), lower [morbidity](/wiki/Morbidity), faster recovery from illness, and a wide range of other effects. [[33]](#cite_note-Bonanni-33) [[34]](#cite_note-Stanciu-34) Those who are older often display less of a response than those who are younger, a pattern known as [Immunosenescence](/wiki/Immunosenescence). [[35]](#cite_note-Frasca-35) [Adjuvants](/wiki/Immunologic_adjuvant) commonly are used to boost immune response, particularly for older people whose immune response to a simple vaccine may have weakened. [[36]](#cite_note-neighmond2010-36) The [efficacy](/wiki/Vaccine_efficacy) or performance of the vaccine is dependent on several factors: - the disease itself (for some diseases vaccination performs better than for others) - the strain of vaccine (some vaccines are specific to, or at least most effective against, particular strains of the disease) [[37]](#cite_note-pmid10435956-37) - whether the [vaccination schedule](/wiki/Vaccination_schedule)has been properly observed. - idiosyncratic response to vaccination; some individuals are "non-responders" to certain vaccines, meaning that they do not generate antibodies even after being vaccinated correctly. - assorted factors such as ethnicity, age, or genetic predisposition. If a vaccinated individual does develop the disease vaccinated against ( [breakthrough infection](/wiki/Breakthrough_infection)), the disease is likely to be less virulent than in unvaccinated cases. [[38]](#cite_note-pmid12955637-38) Important considerations in an effective vaccination program: [[39]](#cite_note-39) - careful modeling to anticipate the effect that an immunization campaign will have on the epidemiology of the disease in the medium to long term - ongoing surveillance for the relevant disease following introduction of a new vaccine - maintenance of high immunization rates, even when a disease has become rare In 1958, there were 763,094 cases of measles in the United States; 552 deaths resulted. [[40]](#cite_note-pmid15106120-40) [[41]](#cite_note-pmid18463608-41) After the introduction of new vaccines, the number of cases dropped to fewer than 150 per year (median of 56). [[41]](#cite_note-pmid18463608-41) In early 2008, there were 64 suspected cases of measles. Fifty-four of those infections were associated with importation from another country, although only thirteen percent were actually acquired outside the United States; 63 of the 64 individuals either had never been vaccinated against measles or were uncertain whether they had been vaccinated. [[41]](#cite_note-pmid18463608-41) Vaccines led to the eradication of [smallpox](/wiki/Smallpox), one of the most contagious and deadly diseases in humans. [[42]](#cite_note-42) Other diseases such as rubella, [polio](/wiki/Poliomyelitis), measles, mumps, [chickenpox](/wiki/Chickenpox), and [typhoid](/wiki/Typhoid_fever) are nowhere near as common as they were a hundred years ago thanks to widespread vaccination programs. As long as the vast majority of people are vaccinated, it is much more difficult for an outbreak of disease to occur, let alone spread. This effect is called [herd immunity](/wiki/Herd_immunity). Polio, which is transmitted only among humans, is targeted by an extensive [eradication campaign](/wiki/Poliomyelitis_eradication) that has seen endemic polio restricted to only parts of three countries (Afghanistan, Nigeria, and Pakistan). [[43]](#cite_note-eradication1-43) However, the difficulty of reaching all children, cultural misunderstandings, and [disinformation](/wiki/Disinformation) have caused the anticipated eradication date to be missed several times. [[44]](#cite_note-44) [[45]](#cite_note-45) [[46]](#cite_note-46) [[47]](#cite_note-47) Vaccines also help prevent the development of antibiotic resistance. For example, by greatly reducing the incidence of pneumonia caused by [Streptococcus pneumoniae](/wiki/Streptococcus_pneumoniae), vaccine programs have greatly reduced the prevalence of infections resistant to penicillin or other first-line antibiotics. [[48]](#cite_note-48) The measles vaccine is estimated to prevent a million deaths every year. [[49]](#cite_note-sullivan2005-49) Adverse effects Vaccinations given to children, adolescents, or adults are generally safe. [[50]](#cite_note-50) [[51]](#cite_note-Mag2014-51) Adverse effects, if any, are generally mild. [[52]](#cite_note-CDC2013-52) The rate of side effects depends on the vaccine in question. [[52]](#cite_note-CDC2013-52) Some common side effects include fever, pain around the injection site, and muscle aches. [[52]](#cite_note-CDC2013-52) Additionally, some individuals may be allergic to ingredients in the vaccine. [[53]](#cite_note-53) [MMR vaccine](/wiki/MMR_vaccine) is rarely associated with [febrile seizures](/wiki/Febrile_seizure). [[51]](#cite_note-Mag2014-51) Host-("vaccinee")-related determinants that render a person susceptible to infection, such as [genetics](/wiki/Genetics), health status (underlying disease, nutrition, pregnancy, [sensitivities](/wiki/Hypersensitivity) or competence](/wiki/Immunocompetence), age, and [economic impact](/wiki/Economic_impact_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic) or [cultural environment](/wiki/Synthetic_psychological_environment) can be primary or secondary factors affecting the severity of infection and response to a vaccine. [[26]](#cite_note-wied-26) Elderly (above age 60), [allergen-hypersensitive](/wiki/Type_I_hypersensitivity), and [obese](/wiki/Obesity) people have susceptibility to compromised [immunogenicity](/wiki/Immunogenicity), which prevents or inhibits vaccine effectiveness, possibly requiring separate vaccine technologies for these specific populations or repetitive [booster vaccinations](/wiki/Booster_dose) to limit [virus transmission](/wiki/Transmission_(medicine)). [[26]](#cite_note-wied-26) Severe side effects are extremely rare. [[51]](#cite_note-Mag2014-51) [Varicella vaccine](/wiki/Varicella_vaccine) is rarely associated with complications in [immunodeficient](/wiki/Immunodeficient) individuals, and [rotavirus vaccines](/wiki/Rotavirus_vaccine) are moderately associated with [intussusception](/wiki/Intussusception_(medical_disorder)). [[51]](#cite_note-Mag2014-51) At least 19 countries have no-fault compensation programs to provide compensation for those with severe adverse effects of vaccination. [[54]](#cite_note-54) The United States' program is known as the [National Childhood Vaccine Injury Act](/wiki/National_Childhood_Vaccine_Injury_Act), and the United Kingdom employs the [Vaccine Damage Payment](/wiki/Vaccine_Damage_Payment). Types Vaccines typically contain attenuated, inactivated or dead organisms or purified products derived from them. There are several types of vaccines in use. [[55]](#cite_note-55) These represent different strategies used to try to reduce the risk of illness while retaining the ability to induce a beneficial immune response. Attenuated Some vaccines contain live, [attenuated](/wiki/Attenuated_vaccine) microorganisms. Many of these are active [viruses](/wiki/Viruses) that have been cultivated under conditions that disable their virulent properties, or that use closely related but less dangerous organisms to produce a broad immune response. Although most attenuated vaccines are viral, some are bacterial in nature. Examples include the viral diseases [yellow fever](/wiki/Yellow_fever), [measles](/wiki/Measles), [mumps](/wiki/Mumps), and [rubella](/wiki/Rubella), and the bacterial live Mycobacterium [tuberculosis](/wiki/Tuberculosis) vaccine developed by Calmette and Guérin is not made of a [contagious](/wiki/Infectious_disease) strain but contains a virulently modified strain called " [BCG](/wiki/Bacillus_Calmette-Gu%C3%A9rin)" used to elicit an immune response to the vaccine. The live attenuated vaccine containing strain [Yersinia pestis](/wiki/Yersinia_pestis) EV is used for plague immunization. Attenuated vaccines have some advantages and disadvantages. Attenuated, or live, weakened, vaccines typically provoke more durable immunological responses. But they may not be safe for use in immunocompromised individuals, and on rare occasions mutate to a virulent form and cause disease. [[56]](#cite_note-Bhattacharya-56) Inactivated Some vaccines contain inactivated, but previously virulent, micro-organisms that have been destroyed with chemicals, heat, or radiation [[57]](#cite_note-57) - "ghosts", with intact but empty bacterial cell envelopes. They are considered an intermediate phase between the inactivated and attenuated vaccines. are made from inactivated toxic compounds that cause illness rather than the micro-organism. [[60]](#cite_note-60) Examples of toxoid-based vaccines include [tetanus](/wiki/Tetanus) and [diphtheria](/wiki/Diphtheria). for example, atrox](/wiki/Crotalus_atrox) toxoid to vaccinate dogs against [rattlesnake](/wiki/Rattlesnake) Subunit Rather than introducing an inactivated or attenuated micro-organism to an immune system (which would constitute a "whole-agent" vaccine), a [subunit](/wiki/Protein_subunit) vaccine uses a fragment of it to create an immune response. One example is the subunit vaccine against [hepatitis B](/wiki/Hepatitis_B#Virology), which is composed of only the surface proteins of the virus (previously extracted from the [blood serum](/wiki/Blood_serum) of chronically infected patients but now produced by [recombination](/wiki/Recombinant_DNA) of the viral genes into [yeast](/wiki/Yeast)). [[62]](#cite_note-62) Another example is [edible algae vaccines](/wiki/Edible_algae_vaccine), particle](/wiki/Virus-like_particle) (VLP) vaccine against [human papillomavirus](/wiki/Human_papillomavirus) (HPV), which is composed of the viral major [capsid](/wiki/Capsid) protein. [[63]](#cite_note-63) Another example is the [hemagglutinin](/wiki/Hemagglutinin) and [neuraminidase](/wiki/Neuraminidase) subunits of the [influenza](/wiki/Influenza) virus. [[59]](#cite_note-historyofvaccines.org-59) A subunit vaccine is being used for plague immunization. [[64]](#cite_note-64) Conjugate Certain bacteria have a [polysaccharide](/wiki/Polysaccharide) [outer coat](/wiki/Bacterial_capsule) that is poorly [immunogenic](/wiki/Immunogenic). By linking these outer coats to proteins (e.g., toxins), the [immune system](/wiki/Immune_system) can be led to recognize the polysaccharide as if it were a protein antigen. This approach is used in the [Haemophilus influenzae type B vaccine](/wiki/Hib_vaccine). [[65]](#cite_note-65) vesicles](/wiki/Bacterial_outer_membrane_vesicles) (OMVs) are naturally immunogenic and can be manipulated to produce potent vaccines. The best known OMV vaccines are those developed are vaccines that are pathogens of other animals that either do not cause disease or cause mild disease in the organism being treated. The classic example is Jenner's use of cowpox to protect against smallpox. A current example is the use of [BCG vaccine](/wiki/BCG_vaccine) made from [Mycobacterium bovis](/wiki/Mycobacterium_bovis) to protect against [tuberculosis](/wiki/Tuberculosis). [[68]](#cite_note-68) Genetic vaccine The subgroup of [genetic vaccines](/wiki/Genetic_vaccine) encompass viral vector vaccines, RNA vaccines and DNA vaccines. Viral vector Viral vector vaccines use a safe [virus](/wiki/Virus) to insert pathogen genes in the body to produce specific [antigens](/wiki/Antigen), such as surface [proteins](/wiki/Protein), to stimulate an [immune [[70]](#cite_note-70) RNA An mRNA vaccine (or [RNA vaccine](/wiki/RNA_vaccine)) is a novel type of vaccine which is composed of the nucleic acid RNA, packaged within a vector such as lipid nanoparticles. [[71]](#cite_note-71) Among the [COVID-19 vaccines](/wiki/COVID-19_vaccine) are a number of RNA vaccines to combat the [COVID-19 pandemic](/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic) and some have been approved or have received [emergency use authorization](/wiki/Emergency_use_authorization) in some countries. For example, the [Pfizer-BioNTech](/wiki/Pfizer%E2%80%93BioNTech_COVID-19_vaccine) vaccine and [Moderna mRNA](/wiki/Moderna_COVID-19_vaccine) vaccine are approved for use in adults and children in the US. [[72]](#cite_note-72) [[73]](#cite_note-73) [[74]](#cite_note-74) DNA [DNA vaccination](/wiki/DNA_vaccination) - The proposed mechanism is the [insertion](/wiki/Insertion_(genetics)) and [expression](/wiki/Gene_expression) of viral or bacterial DNA in human or animal cells (enhanced by the use of [electroporation](/wiki/Electroporation)), triggering immune system recognition. Some cells of the immune system that recognize the proteins expressed will mount an attack against these proteins and cells expressing them. Because these cells live for a very long time, if the [pathogen](/wiki/Pathogen) that normally expresses these proteins is encountered at a later time, they will be attacked instantly by the immune system. One potential advantage of DNA vaccines is that they are very easy to produce and store. In August 2021, Indian authorities gave emergency approval to [ZyCoV-D](/wiki/ZyCoV-D). Developed by [Cadila Healthcare](/wiki/Cadila_Healthcare), it is the first DNA vaccine approved for humans. Experimental Many innovative vaccines are also in development and use. - Dendritic cell vaccines combine [dendritic cells](/wiki/Dendritic_cell)with antigens to present the antigens to the body's white blood cells, thus stimulating an immune reaction. These vaccines have shown some positive preliminary results for treating brain tumors [[75]](#cite_note-75)and are also tested in malignant melanoma. [[76]](#cite_note-pmid24872109-76) [Recombinant](/wiki/Recombinant_DNA) [vector](/wiki/Viral_vector_vaccine)- by combining the physiology of one micro-organism and the [DNA](/wiki/DNA)of another, immunity can be created against diseases that have complex infection processes. An example is the [RVSV-ZEBOV vaccine](/wiki/RVSV-ZEBOV_vaccine)licensed to Merck that is being used in 2018 to combat [ebola in Congo](/wiki/2017_Democratic_Republic_of_the_Congo_Ebola_virus_outbreak). [[77]](#cite_note-77) [T-cell receptor](/wiki/T-cell_receptor)peptide vaccines are under development for several using models of [Valley Fever](/wiki/Valley_Fever), [stomatitis](/wiki/Stomatitis), and [atopic dermatitis](/wiki/Atopic_dermatitis). These peptides have been shown to modulate [cytokine](/wiki/Cytokine)production and improve cell-mediated immunity. - Targeting of identified bacterial proteins that are involved in complement inhibition would neutralize the key bacterial virulence mechanism. [[78]](#cite_note-pmid19388175-78) - The use of [plasmids](/wiki/Plasmid)has been validated in preclinical studies as a protective vaccine strategy for cancer and infectious diseases. However, in human studies, this approach has failed to provide clinically relevant benefit. The overall efficacy of plasmid DNA immunization depends on increasing the plasmid's [immunogenicity](/wiki/Immunogenicity)while also correcting for factors involved in the specific activation of immune effector cells. [[79]](#cite_note-Lowe-79) [Bacterial vector](/wiki/Vector_(epidemiology))- Similar in principle to using bacteria instead. [[66]](#cite_note-vaccinology-guide-66) [Antigen-presenting cell](/wiki/Antigen-presenting_cell_vaccine) [[66]](#cite_note-vaccinology-guide-66) While most vaccines are or attenuated compounds from micro-organisms, [synthetic vaccines](/wiki/Synthetic_vaccine) are composed mainly or wholly of synthetic peptides, carbohydrates, or antigens. Valence Vaccines may be monovalent (also called univalent) or multivalent (also called polyvalent). A monovalent vaccine is designed to immunize against a single antigen or single microorganism. [[80]](#cite_note-80) A multivalent or polyvalent vaccine is designed to immunize against two or more strains of the same microorganism, or against two or more microorganisms. [[81]](#cite_note-81) The valency of a multivalent vaccine may be denoted with a Greek or Latin prefix (e.g., bivalent, trivalent, or tetravalent/quadrivalent). In certain cases, a monovalent vaccine may be preferable for rapidly developing a strong immune response. [[82]](#cite_note-82) Interactions When two or more vaccines are mixed in the same formulation, the two vaccines can interfere. This most frequently occurs with live attenuated vaccines, where one of the vaccine components is more robust than the others and suppresses the growth and immune response to the other components. This phenomenon was first[ [when?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items)] noted in the trivalent Sabin [polio vaccine](/wiki/Polio_vaccine), where the amount of serotype 2 virus in the vaccine had to be reduced to stop it from interfering with the "take" of the serotype 1 and 3 viruses in the vaccine. [[83]](#cite_note-83) It was also noted in a 2001 study to be a problem with [dengue](/wiki/Dengue) vaccines, where the DEN-3 serotype was found to predominate and suppress the response to DEN-1, -2 and -4 serotypes. [[84]](#cite_note-84) Other contents [immunogen](/wiki/Immunogen). A single dose may have merely nanograms of virus particles, or micrograms of bacterial polysaccharides. A vaccine injection, oral drops or nasal spray is mostly water. Other ingredients are added to boost the immune response, to ensure safety or help with storage, and a tiny amount of material is left-over from the manufacturing process. Very rarely, these materials can cause an allergic reaction in people who are very sensitive to them. Adjuvants Vaccines typically contain one or more [adjuvants](/wiki/Adjuvant), used to boost the immune response. Tetanus toxoid, for instance, is usually adsorbed onto [alum](/wiki/Alum). This presents the antigen in such a way as to produce a greater action than the simple aqueous tetanus toxoid. People who have an adverse reaction to adsorbed tetanus toxoid may be given the simple vaccine when the time comes for a booster. [[85]](#cite_note-85) In the preparation for the 1990 Persian Gulf campaign, the whole cell [pertussis](/wiki/Pertussis) vaccine was used as an adjuvant for [anthrax](/wiki/Anthrax) vaccine. This produces a more rapid immune response than giving only the anthrax vaccine, which is of some benefit if exposure might be imminent. [[86]](#cite_note-86) Preservatives Vaccines may also contain preservatives to prevent contamination with [bacteria](/wiki/Bacteria) or [fungi](/wiki/Fungi). Until recent years, the preservative [thiomersal](/wiki/Thiomersal) (a.k.a. Thimerosal in the US and Japan) was used in many vaccines that did not contain live viruses. As of 2005, the only childhood vaccine in the U.S. that contains thiomersal in greater than trace amounts is the influenza vaccine, [[87]](#cite_note-87) which is currently recommended only for children with certain risk factors. [[88]](#cite_note-88) Single-dose influenza vaccines supplied in the UK do not list thiomersal in the ingredients. Preservatives may be used at various stages of the production of vaccines, and the most sophisticated methods of measurement might detect traces of them in the finished product, as they may in the environment and population as a whole. [[89]](#cite_note-89) Many vaccines need preservatives to prevent serious adverse effects such as [Staphylococcus](/wiki/Staphylococcus) infection, which in one 1928 incident killed 12 of 21 children inoculated with a [diphtheria](/wiki/Diphtheria) vaccine that lacked a preservative. [[90]](#cite_note-90) preservatives are available, including thiomersal, [phenoxyethanol](/wiki/Phenoxyethanol), and [formaldehyde](/wiki/Formaldehyde). Thiomersal is more effective against bacteria, has a better shelf-life, and improves vaccine stability, potency, and safety; but, in the U.S., the [European Union](/wiki/European_Union), and a few other affluent countries, it is no longer used as a preservative in childhood vaccines, as a precautionary measure due to its [mercury](/wiki/Mercury_(element)) content. [[91]](#cite_note-91) Although [controversial claims](/wiki/Thiomersal_controversy) have been made that thiomersal contributes to [autism](/wiki/Autism_spectrum_disorder), no convincing scientific evidence supports these claims. [[92]](#cite_note-92) Furthermore, a 10-11-year study of 657,461 children found that the MMR vaccine does not cause autism and actually reduced the risk of autism by seven percent. [[93]](#cite_note-93) [[94]](#cite_note-94) Excipients Beside the active vaccine itself, the following [excipients](/wiki/Excipient) and residual manufacturing compounds are present or may be present in vaccine preparations: [[95]](#cite_note-cdc-95) [Aluminum](/wiki/Aluminum)salts or gels are added as [adjuvants](/wiki/Adjuvant). Adjuvants are added to promote an earlier, more potent response, and more persistent immune response to the vaccine; they allow for a lower vaccine dosage. [Antibiotics](/wiki/Antibiotic)are added to some vaccines to prevent the growth of bacteria during production and storage of the vaccine. - Egg [protein](/wiki/Protein)is present in the [influenza vaccine](/wiki/Influenza_vaccine)and [yellow fever vaccine](/wiki/Yellow_fever_vaccine)as they are prepared using chicken eggs. Other proteins may be present. [Formaldehyde](/wiki/Formaldehyde)is used to inactivate bacterial products for toxoid vaccines. Formaldehyde is also used to inactivate unwanted viruses and kill bacteria that might contaminate the vaccine during production. [Monosodium glutamate](/wiki/Monosodium_glutamate)(MSG) and 2- [phenoxyethanol](/wiki/Phenoxyethanol)are used as stabilizers in a few vaccines to help the vaccine remain unchanged when the vaccine is exposed to heat, light, acidity, or humidity. [Thiomersal](/wiki/Thiomersal)is a mercury-containing antimicrobial that is added to vials of vaccines that contain more than one dose to prevent contamination and growth of potentially harmful bacteria. Due to the controversy surrounding thiomersal, it has been removed from most vaccines except multi-use influenza, where it was reduced to levels so that a single dose contained less than a microgram of mercury, a level similar to eating ten grams of canned tuna. [[96]](#cite_note-FDA-96) Nomenclature Various fairly standardized abbreviations for vaccine names have developed, although the standardization is by no means centralized or global. For example, the vaccine names used in the United States have well-established abbreviations that are also widely known and used elsewhere. An extensive list of them provided in a sortable table and freely accessible is available at a US [Centers for Disease Control and Prevention](/wiki/Centers_for_Disease_Control_and_Prevention) web page. [[97]](#cite_note-CDC_US_vaccine_names-97) The page explains that "The abbreviations [in] this table (Column 3) were standardized jointly by staff of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, [ACIP](/wiki/Advisory_Committee_on_Immunization_Practices) Work Groups, the editor of the [Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report](/wiki/Morbidity_and_Mortality_Weekly_Report) (MMWR), the editor of Epidemiology and Prevention of Vaccine-Preventable Diseases (the Pink Book), ACIP members, and liaison organizations to the ACIP." [[97]](#cite_note-CDC_US_vaccine_names-97) Some examples are " [DTaP](/wiki/DTaP)" for diphtheria and tetanus toxoids and [acellular](/wiki/Acellular) pertussis vaccine, "DT" for diphtheria and tetanus toxoids, and "Td" for tetanus and diphtheria toxoids. Lower-case "d" and "p" denote reduced doses of diphtheria and pertussis used in the adolescent/adult-formulations. [[120]](#cite_note-120) Patents According to the World Health Organization, the biggest barrier to vaccine production in less developed countries has not been [patents](/wiki/Patent), but the substantial financial, [infrastructure](/wiki/Infrastructure), and workforce requirements needed for market entry. The vaccine produced by a new facility must undergo complete clinical testing for safety and efficacy by the manufacturer. For most vaccines, specific processes in technology are patented. These can be circumvented by alternative manufacturing methods, but this required R&D infrastructure and a suitably skilled workforce. In the case of a few relatively new vaccines, such as the [human papillomavirus](/wiki/Human_papillomavirus) vaccine, the patents may impose an additional barrier. [[122]](#cite_note-somos-122) Production Vaccine production is fundamentally different from other kinds of manufacturing - including regular [pharmaceutical manufacturing](/wiki/Pharmaceutical_manufacturing) - in that vaccines are intended to be administered to millions of people of whom the vast majority are perfectly healthy. [[123]](#cite_note-Plotkin_Page_45-123) This fact drives an extraordinarily rigorous production process with strict compliance requirements that go far beyond what is required of other products. [[123]](#cite_note-Plotkin_Page_45-123) Depending upon the antigen, it can cost anywhere from US$50 to $500 million to build a vaccine production facility, which requires highly specialized equipment, [clean rooms](/wiki/Cleanroom), and containment rooms. [[124]](#cite_note-Plotkin_2017-124) There is a global scarcity of personnel with the right combination of skills, expertise, knowledge, competence and personality to staff vaccine production lines. [[124]](#cite_note-Plotkin_2017-124) With the notable exceptions of Brazil, China, and India, many developing countries' educational systems are unable to provide enough qualified candidates, and vaccine makers based in such countries must hire expatriate personnel to keep production going. [[124]](#cite_note-Plotkin_2017-124) Vaccine production has several stages. First, the antigen itself is generated. Viruses are grown either on primary cells such as [chicken eggs](/wiki/Chicken_as_biological_research_model) (e.g., for influenza) or on continuous cell lines such as cultured human cells (e.g., for [hepatitis A](/wiki/Hepatitis_A)). [[125]](#cite_note-125) Bacteria are grown in [bioreactors](/wiki/Bioreactor) (e.g., [Haemophilus influenzae](/wiki/Haemophilus_influenzae) type b). Likewise, a recombinant protein derived from the viruses or bacteria can be generated in yeast, bacteria, or cell cultures. [[126]](#cite_note-:0-126) [[127]](#cite_note-WHOVaccSafety2-127) After the antigen is generated, it is isolated from the cells used to generate it. A virus may need to be inactivated, possibly with no further purification required. Recombinant proteins need many operations involving ultrafiltration and column chromatography. Finally, the vaccine is formulated by adding adjuvant, stabilizers, and preservatives as needed. The adjuvant enhances the immune response to the antigen, stabilizers increase the storage life, and preservatives allow the use of multidose vials. [[126]](#cite_note-:0-126) [[127]](#cite_note-WHOVaccSafety2-127) Combination vaccines are harder to develop and produce, because of potential incompatibilities and interactions among the antigens and other ingredients involved. [[128]](#cite_note-Bae-128) The final stage in vaccine manufacture before distribution is [fill and finish](/wiki/Fill_and_finish), which is the process of filling vials with vaccines and packaging them for distribution. Although this is a conceptually simple part of the vaccine manufacture process, it is often a bottleneck in the process of distributing and administering vaccines. [[129]](#cite_note-129) [[130]](#cite_note-130) [[131]](#cite_note-131) Vaccine production techniques are evolving.
